name: cookiecutter-python-package
description: Create Python Packages, with emphasis on CI/CD and automation, from a template.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://python-package-generator.readthedocs.io
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification:
There is the intention to release interim versions of the package.
These versions shall also coincide with a "pre-release" version.
The version string shall follow "semantic versioning" (see semver.org) and match with pattern: MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH-dev.X
where X shall be a non negative integer starting from 0. Incremental values of X shall simply indicate a more "mature" pre-release version.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
PyPI hosts the releases, each of which has a unique version identifier:

https://pypi.org/project/cookiecutter-python/0.8.2/
https://pypi.org/project/cookiecutter-python/0.8.1/
https://pypi.org/project/cookiecutter-python/0.7.2/
version_tags_justification:
Each github release is associated to a unique git tag:

https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/releases/tag/v0.8.2
https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/releases/tag/v0.8.1
https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/releases/tag/v0.7.2
test_justification:
It is documented that the test suite runs with pytest and tox.
It is documented that the CI pipeline triggers on pushed to the remote.
test_most_justification: Test Suite covers indeed most of the above.
tests_documented_added_justification: The policy of adding tests is described in https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
warnings_fixed_justification:
No warnings trigger on CI for all Jobs that run:
See: https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/actions
warnings_strict_justification:
We do not suppress any warnings when running our CI:
See "tox" and "github actions workflow" configuration files:

https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/.github/workflows/test.yaml
https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/tox.ini
static_analysis_justification:
We use mypy, which is part of the CI Test Workflow running on Github Actions: https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/actions/

We use Pyflakes: A simple program which checks Python source files for errors.

We use Pyroma

We use Dodgy

We use McCabe complexity checker for Python
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j:
We run Bandit, which is an established python tool to check security/vulnerability issues on static code, on every Opened Pull request as part of the CI integration with Codacy.
See: https://app.codacy.com/gh/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/dashboard
static_analysis_fixed_justification:
We run Bandit, which is an established python tool to check security/vulnerability issues on static code, on every Opened Pull request as part of the CI integration with Codacy.
See: https://app.codacy.com/gh/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/dashboard
static_analysis_often_justification: We use mypy, which is part of the CI Test Workflow that triggers on every commit to dev and master branches (running on Github Actions): https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/actions/
dynamic_analysis_justification:
We have enabled a 3-factor build matrix to stress test the package.
Each Job runs the Test Suite on an environment defined by a python version (1st factor: 3.6, 3.7, 3.8, 3.9, 3.10), by a platform (2nd factor: Linux, MacOS) and by package installation type (3rd factor: just putting the package under test into PYTHONPATH, installing an sdist after building the package, or installing a wheel after building the package).

This is achieved with a combination of github action workflow config file (see https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/.github/workflows/test.yaml), a tox.ini file (see https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/tox.ini), and the tox-gh-actions python module).

This is also visible on the Github Actions interface (see https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/actions) where by clicking on a Workflow run, each Job spawned based on the build matrix is visible on the left-side pane.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The project does not produce software written in a memory-unsafe language.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi:
We have enabled a 3-factor build matrix to stress test the package.
Each Job runs the Test Suite on an environment defined by a python version (1st factor: 3.6, 3.7, 3.8, 3.9, 3.10), by a platform (2nd factor: Linux, MacOS) and by package installation type (3rd factor: just putting the package under test into PYTHONPATH, installing an sdist after building the package, or installing a wheel after building the package).

This is achieved with a combination of github action workflow config file (see https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/.github/workflows/test.yaml), a tox.ini file (see https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/tox.ini), and the tox-gh-actions python module).

This is also visible on the Github Actions interface (see https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/actions) where by clicking on a Workflow run, each Job spawned based on the build matrix is visible on the left-side pane.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification:
We have enabled a 3-factor build matrix to stress test the package.
Each Job runs the Test Suite on an environment defined by a python version (1st factor: 3.6, 3.7, 3.8, 3.9, 3.10), by a platform (2nd factor: Linux, MacOS) and by package installation type (3rd factor: just putting the package under test into PYTHONPATH, installing an sdist after building the package, or installing a wheel after building the package).

This is achieved with a combination of github action workflow config file (see https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/.github/workflows/test.yaml), a tox.ini file (see https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/tox.ini), and the tox-gh-actions python module).

This is also visible on the Github Actions interface (see https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/actions) where by clicking on a Workflow run, each Job spawned based on the build matrix is visible on the left-side pane.

If the CI is not passing we make a fix.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The project uses and required passing continuous integrations for all pull request and changes: https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/actions
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
installation_common_justification: We use pip for install/uninstall or git commands.
documentation_current_justification:
We have enabled CI with the "read the docs server" (readthedocs.org) that builds and hosts new documentation on every commit on the "dev" and "master" branches.
See https://python-package-generator.readthedocs.io/en/master/ for the docs
See https://readthedocs.org/projects/python-package-generator/ for the readthedocs CI build configurations
documentation_achievements_justification:
We have a badge on the README.rst which is the landing page for the Project source code, hosted on Github.
See https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: There have been no vulnerabilities resolved in the last 12 months.
coding_standards_justification:
There is the CONTRIBUTING guide at https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
And also we have enabled CI with the codacy server (see https://app.codacy.com/gh/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/dashboard?branch=master)
that automatically run Checks, including coding style checks, on every pull request.
build_non_recursive_justification: This is not applicable to our build command, which is "python3 -m build"
build_repeatable_justification: This is met from our "build command": python3 -m build
installation_standard_variables_justific:
We use pip as our installation system.
In the python ecosystem, pip honors the standard conventions for selecting the installation location.
installation_development_quick_justifica: We use tox to automate everything for developers.
external_dependencies_justification:
All external dependencies are defined in pyproject.toml and/or setup.cfg. These files list the external dependencies in a computer-processable way when using standard "python build" modules (such as build, poetry, setuptools).

https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/setup.cfg
https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/pyproject.toml
test_policy_mandated_justification: This is stated in the CONTRIBUTING guide. See https://github.com/boromir674/cookiecutter-python-package/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

report_responses_justification: On-call engineer responds within 1-business day to security-related bugs. Product management team triages all other bugs weekly.
enhancement_responses_justification: Product management team triages all other bugs weekly.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: On-call engineers responds to vulnerability reports within 1 business day.
warnings_justification:
We build the project with Java's -Werror flag, it fails the build if there are warnings
There is also a linter that must pass: https://github.com/seattle-uat/civiform/blob/main/formatter.Dockerfile
warnings_fixed_justification: We build the project with Java's -Werror flag, it fails the build if there are warnings
warnings_strict_justification: We build the project with Java's -Werror flag, it fails the build if there are warnings. Also google errorprone library.
know_secure_design_justification: Lead developer on the project is familiar with these principles: https://www.linkedin.com/in/bionjohnson/
know_common_errors_justification: Lead developer on the project is familiar with these principles: https://www.linkedin.com/in/bionjohnson/

crypto_call_justification: We use pac4j and google's Guava library for cryptography.
crypto_floss_justification: We use pac4j and google's Guava library for cryptography.
crypto_keylength_justification: We use pac4j and google's Guava library for cryptography. Keylength of 256 bits for upcoming API keys feature
crypto_working_justification: We use pac4j and google's Guava library for cryptography.
crypto_password_storage_justification: We rely on 3p services for authentication over OIDC and SAML
crypto_random_justification: We use pac4j and google's Guava library for cryptography.
delivery_mitm_justification: Deployments are done using major cloud provider CLI tools (GCP, Azure, AWS)
static_analysis_justification: we use google's errorprone analysis tool https://github.com/seattle-uat/civiform/blob/main/server/build.sbt#L94
static_analysis_fixed_justification: On-call engineer responds to severe vulnerabilities within 1 business day
